newsitem.title: TANZANIA: Inquiry blames Tanzanian railways for ship disaster.
newsitem.headline: Inquiry blames Tanzanian railways for ship disaster.

text.p: A Tanzanian government report has blamed the country's state-run railways for the disaster which claimed 700 lives in May when one of its ships capsized on Lake Victoria.
Transport Minister William Kusila released the report by a commission of inquiry which said Tanzania Railways Corporation (TRC) had failed to appreciate the danger of operating an unstable ship.
"TRC marine operations were characterised by gross negligence, inefficiency, corruption and other malpractices," it said.

The 195-foot Bukoba, which operated regular passenger and cargo services between Lake Victoria ports, had a capacity of 441 passengers, but was believed to be carrying more 1,000 people when it capsized near the port of Mwanza.

It added: "TRC, including personnel both on shore and on board the ship, must take a large share of the blame for the accident for failure to appreciate fully the gravity of the problem of a dangerous vessel, and failing to exercise the necessary caution that the operation of such a ship required at all times."
After the disaster, the ship's captain was arrested but later released. Kusila said the police would decide whether any charges should be laid in light of the inquiry's report.
